Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref> |established_title = [[Municipal corporation|Incorporated]] |established_date = July 31, 1894 |area_magnitude = |area_total_sq_mi = 1.5 |area_total_km2 = 3.9 |area_land_sq_mi = 1.5 |area_land_km2 = 3.9 |area_water_sq_mi = 0.0 |area_water_km2 = 0.0 |area_urban_sq_mi = |area_urban_km2 = |area_metro_sq_mi = |area_metro_km2 = |population_as_of = 2010 |population_footnotes = <ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web| url=http://factfinder2.census.gov| title=Race, Hispanic or Latino, Age, and Housing Occupancy: 2010 Census Redistricting Data (Public Law 94-171) Summary File (QT-PL), Hasbrouck Heights borough, New Jersey| publisher=U.S. Census Bureau, American FactFinder 2| accessdate=July 29, 2011}}</ref> |population_total = 11842 |population_metro = |population_urban = |population_density_km2 = auto |population_density_sq_mi = |timezone = [[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern (EST]] |utc_offset = -5 |timezone_DST = EDT |utc_offset_DST = -4 |coordinates_display = display=inline,title |latd = 40 |latm = 51 |lats = 46 |latNS = N |longd = 74 |longm = 4 |longs = 30 |longEW = W |elevation_m = 35 |elevation_ft = 115 |elevation_footnotes = <ref>{{Gnis|885247|Borough of Hasbrouck Heights}}, [[Geographic Names Information System]], accessed April 16, 2007.</ref> |postal_code_type = ZIP code |postal_code = 07604 |area_code = [[Area code 201|201]] |website = http://www.hasbrouck-heights.nj.us |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = 34-30420{{GR|2}}<ref>[http://mcdc2.missouri.edu/webrepts/commoncodes/ccc_nj.html A Cure for the Common Codes: New Jersey], Missouri Census Data Center. Accessed July 14, 2008.</ref> |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 0876986{{GR|3}} |footnotes = }} '''Hasbrouck Heights''' (pronounced HAZ-brook) is a [[Borough (New Jersey)|borough]] in [[Bergen County, New Jersey|Bergen County]], [[New Jersey]], United States. As of the [[2010 United States Census|2010 census]], the borough population was 11,842.<ref name="Census 2010"/> An [[inner suburbs|inner-ring suburb]] of [[New York City]], Hasbrouck Heights is located approximately {{convert|10|mi}} northwest of [[Midtown Manhattan]] and {{convert|8|mi|0}} west of [[Upper Manhattan]].
Hasbrouck Heights was formed with the passage of a referendum on July 31, 1894, and was created from portions of [[Lodi Township, New Jersey|Lodi Township]] at the height of the "[[Boroughitis]]" phenomenon then sweeping through Bergen County.<ref>"History of Bergen County" Vol. 1, p. 367-370.</ref> A part of the borough was annexed to [[Lodi, New Jersey|Lodi]] in 1901.<ref>"Municipal Incorporations of the State of New Jersey" p. 11 note 21.</ref>
==Geography== Hasbrouck Heights is located at {{Coord|40.862890|-74.075062|type:city_region:US|format=dms|display=inline}} (40.862890, -74.075062).{{GR|1}}
According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the borough has a total area of {{convert|1.5|sqmi}}, all of it land.
==Demographics== {{USCensusPop | 1900= 1255 | 1910= 2155 | 1920= 2895 | 1930= 5658 | 1940= 6716 | 1950= 9181 | 1960= 13046 | 1970= 13651 | 1980= 12166 | 1990= 11488 | 2000= 11662 | 2010= 11842 | estimate= | estyear= | estref= | footnote=Population 1900 - 1990.<ref>[http://www.co.bergen.nj.us/planning/data/HistoricalPop.pdf Historical Population Trends in Bergen County (1900 - 2000)], [[Bergen County, New Jersey]]. Accessed December 23, 2007.</ref><ref>[http://www.wnjpin.net/OneStopCareerCenter/LaborMarketInformation/lmi01/poptrd6.htm Jersey Resident Population by Municipality: 1930 - 1990], Workforce New Jersey Public Information Network. Accessed March 1, 2007.</ref>- }} As of the [[census]]{{GR|2}} of 2000, there were 11,662 people, 4,521 households, and 3,142 families residing in the borough. The [[population density]] was 7,735.0 people per square mile (2,981.9/km<sup>2</sup>). There were 4,617 housing units at an average density of 3,062.3 per square mile (1,180.6/km<sup>2</sup>). The racial makeup of the borough was 87.87% [[White (U.S. Census)|White]], 1.71% [[African American (U.S. Census)|African American]], 0.04% [[Native American (U.S. Census)|Native American]], 6.65% [[Asian (U.S. Census)|Asian]], 0.01% [[Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)|Pacific Islander]], 2.19% from [[Race (United States Census)|other races]], and 1.53% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)|Hispanic]] or [[Latino (U.S. Census)|Latino]] of any race were 8.27% of the population.
There were 4,521 households out of which 30.8% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 57.1% were [[Marriage|married couples]] living together, 9.4% had a female householder with no husband present, and 30.5% were non-families. 26.2% of all households were made up of individuals and 11.7% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.58 and the average family size was 3.16.
In the borough the population was spread out with 22.2% under the age of 18, 6.5% from 18 to 24, 29.9% from 25 to 44, 24.4% from 45 to 64, and 17.0% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 40 years. For every 100 females there were 92.5 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 89.6 males.
The median income for a household in the borough was $64,529, and the median income for a family was $75,032. Males had a median income of $51,328 versus $40,570 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the borough was $29,626. About 2.1% of families and 4.2% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 6.5% of those under age 18 and 4.5% of those age 65 or over.
==Government== ===Local government=== [[Image:HeightsBoroughHall.jpg|left|380px|thumb| Borough Hall (January 2009)]] Hasbrouck Heights is governed under the [[Borough (New Jersey)|Borough]] form of New Jersey municipal government. The government consists of a Mayor and a Borough Council comprising six council members, with all positions elected at large. A Mayor is elected directly by the voters to a four-year term of office and only votes to break a tie. The Borough Council consists of six members elected to serve three-year terms on a staggered basis, with two seats coming up for election each year.<ref name=DataBook>''2005 New Jersey Legislative District Data Book'', [[Rutgers University]] [[Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy]], April 2005, p. 160.</ref>
{{asof|2011}}, the Mayor of Hasbrouck Heights is [[Rose Marie Heck]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]], 2011). Members of the Hasbrouck Heights Borough Council are Council President David Gonzalez, Sonya Buckman, John Dingertopadre, Justin A. DiPisa, Pamela J. Link and Russell Lipari.<ref>[http://www.hasbrouck-heights.nj.us/general/mc.html Hasbrouck Heights Mayor & Council], Borough of Hasbrouck Heights. Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref>
===Federal, state and county representation=== Hasbrouck Heights is in the 9th Congressional district. {{NJ Congress 09}} {{NJ Senate}}
Hasbrouck Heights is in the {{NJ Legislative 38}}
{{NJ Bergen County Freeholders}}
===Politics=== As of April 1, 2006, out of a 2004 Census estimated population of 11,679 in Hasbrouck Heights, there were 7,119 registered voters (61.0% of the population, vs. 55.4% in all of Bergen County). Of registered voters, 1,018 (14.3% vs. 20.7% countywide) were registered as [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]], 2,712 (38.1% vs. 19.2% countywide) were registered as [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] and 3,386 (47.6% vs. 60.1% countywide) were registered as [[Undeclared (New Jersey)|Undeclared]]. There were three voters registered to other parties.<ref>"County of Bergen: Voter Statistics by Municipality, Ward & District," dated April 1, 2006.</ref>
On the national level, Hasbrouck Heights leans toward the Republican Party. In the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 presidential election]], Republican [[George W. Bush]] received 56% of the vote here, defeating Democrat [[John Kerry]], who received around 43%.<ref>[http://www.nj.gov/lps/elections/2004results/04_Municipality_pdf%27s/presidential_bergen_co_2004.pdf 2004 Presidential Election results: Bergen County], [[New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safety]], Division of Elections, dated December 13, 2004.</ref> In [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008]], Republican [[John McCain]] received 52.9% of the vote, defeating Democrat [[Barack Obama]], who received 45.5%.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.njelections.org/2008results/08generalelection/results-by-municipality/08-gen-elect-presidential-results-bergen.pdf |title=Presidential General Election Results: Bergen County |accessdate=2009-01-25}}</ref>
==Education== [[Image:HeightsHigh.jpg|right|380px|thumb| [[Hasbrouck Heights High School]]]] The [[Hasbrouck Heights School District]] serves public school students in kindergarten through twelfth grade. The district also serves students from Teterboro, a non-operating district that was merged into the Hasbrouck Heights School District following its dissolution on July 1, 2010.<ref>Graham, Dr. Aaron R. [http://www.app.com/assets/pdf/B31677791210.PDF Bergen County Report on Consolidation and Regionalization], Bergen County Executive County Superintendent, March 15, 2010. Accessed June 15, 2011. "Hasbrouck Heights (PK-12) and Teterboro (non-op):The two districts will form the newly merged district of Hasbrouck Heights with Teterboro, a non-operating district scheduled for elimination on July 1, 2010."</ref>
Schools in the district (with 2009-10 enrollment data from the [[National Center for Education Statistics]]<ref>[http://nces.ed.gov/ccd/schoolsearch/school_list.asp?Search=1&DistrictID=3406930 Data for the Hasbrouck Heights School District], [[National Center for Education Statistics]]. Accessed June 15, 2011.</ref>) include two K-5 elementary schools â [http://euclid.hhschools.org/ Euclid School] (371 students) and [http://lincoln.hhschools.org/ Lincoln School] (421) â [http://ms.hhschools.org/ Hasbrouck Heights Middle School] for grades 6-8 (403) and [[Hasbrouck Heights High School]] for grades 9-12 (459).
==Transportation== [[New Jersey Transit]] bus routes [[161 (New Jersey bus)|161]], [[163 (New Jersey bus)|163]] and [[164 (New Jersey bus)|164]] provide service to and from the [[Port Authority Bus Terminal]] in [[Midtown Manhattan]]; the [[76 (New Jersey bus)|76]] line serves [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]]; and local service is offered on the [[709 (New Jersey bus)|709]] and [[780 (New Jersey bus)|780]] routes.<ref>[http://www.njtransit.com/sf/sf_servlet.srv?hdnPageAction=BusRoutesBergenCountyTo Routes by County: Bergen County], [[New Jersey Transit]]. Accessed September 9, 2008.</ref>
[[Image:Bendix Diner.jpg|left|380px|thumb| The Bendix Diner is a prominent landmark on Route 17.]]In addition, NJ Transit provides rail service via the [[Pascack Valley Line]]'s [[Teterboro-Williams Avenue (NJT station)|Williams Avenue]] station, which is located on the boundary of Hasbrouck Heights and [[Teterboro, New Jersey|Teterboro]]. Although the rail line's tracks lie entirely within the municipal boundaries of Hasbrouck Heights - and in fact form the borough's eastern boundary with Teterboro - NJ Transit considers the station to be in Teterboro because its parking lot and ingress/egress roads are accessed from that town.
[[New Jersey Route 17|Route 17]] and [[U.S. Route 46]] both pass through Hasbrouck Heights.
Portions of [[Teterboro Airport]] are located in Hasbrouck Heights.<ref>[http://www.panynj.gov/commutingtravel/airports/html/teb_location.html Directions to and from the Airport], [[Port Authority of New York & New Jersey]]. Accessed July 7, 2008. "Teterboro Airport is located in the Boroughs of Teterboro, Moonachie, and Hasbrouck Heights in Bergen County, New Jersey."</ref>
==Notable events== * 1664 - Settled * 1894 - Incorporated * 1896 - Volunteer fire department established * 1935 - (May 19) Small biplane loses altitude after taking off from Teterboro Airport, and drops directly in front of automobile on Route 2 (now [[New Jersey Route 17|Route 17]]). Driver of automobile only bruised after crash, pilot and student co-pilot severely injured. * 1966 - (June 29) Pilot James P. Scott crash-lands his [[Piper Aztec]] twin-engine plane on front lawn of Burton Avenue home after losing an engine and skimming the top of a tree, which softened his landing. The plane slid up the driveway and struck the house. The residents were not at home, and the pilot survived. * 1999 - (December 9) A plane bound for neighboring Teterboro Airport crashes in a backyard. Three aboard died, no injuries occurred on the ground. * 1999 - (December 10) The Municipal Building (town hall, town court, fire department, police department) catches fire. The cause of the blaze was found to be an electrical problem. A new building was built on the Boulevard and Central and dedicated on December 14, 2003. * 2006 - (June) The [[public library]] director Michele Reutty was in the news for not providing information to the town [[police]] when they turned up at the library without a [[subpoena]].<ref>[http://www.northjersey.com/page.php?qstr=eXJpcnk3ZjczN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXk2MDYmZmdiZWw3Zjd2cWVlRUV5eTY5NTE1NjImeXJpcnk3ZjcxN2Y3dnFlZUVFeXkz Library chief draws cops' ire], ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', June 22, 2006.</ref> This event drew widespread attention via a [[Slashdot]] article.<ref>[http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=06/06/22/2251209 Slashdot: Library Chief Criticized for Requiring Subpoena]</ref>
==Notable residents== Notable current and former residents of Hasbrouck Heights include: * [[Joe Benigno]] (born 1953), sports radio personality on [[WFAN]]<ref>Davidoff, Ken. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-22397475.html "See more articles from The Record (Bergen County, NJ)"], ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', June 1, 1997. Accessed November 30, 2008.</ref> * [[Jason Biggs]] (born 1978), actor, attended Hasbrouck Heights High School<ref>Ivry, Bob. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-22253564.html "BUT MOM LOVES HIM ANYWAY -- WITH `AMERICAN PIE,' JASON BIGGS TAKES A PECULIAR PATH FROM HASBROUCK HEIGHTS TO HOLLYWOOD CELEBRITY"], ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', July 7, 1999. Accessed June 4, 2007.</ref> * [[Frank W. Burr]] (1906â92), mayor of [[Teaneck, New Jersey]] from 1970-74<ref>Voreacos, David. [http://www.teaneck.org/virtualvillage/mayors/burr/burr.html "Frank Burr, Civic Leader, Former Mayor of Teaneck"], copy of article from ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', May 5, 1992. Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref> * [[Marian Calabro]], author and publisher of history books and the founder and president of CorporateHistory.net * [[Vincent J. Dellay]] (1907â99), represented New Jersey for one term in the [[United States House of Representatives]]<ref>via [[Associated Press]]. [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AC&p_theme=ac&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAEAE893549230A&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM "VINCENT DELLAY, FORMER CONGRESSMAN, DIES AT 91"], ''[[The Press of Atlantic City]]'', April 19, 1999. Accessed March 7, 2011. "Dellay, of Hasbrouck Heights, died Friday at the Hackensack University Medical Center."</ref> * [[Arthur Godfrey]] (1903â1983), entertainer<ref>Emblen, Frank. [http://select.nytimes.com/search/restricted/article?res=F50E13F93C5C0C7B8DDDAB0994DB484D81 "NEW JERSEY GUIDE"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 18, 1983. Accessed November 7, 2007. "Mr. Godfrey, who died on March 16 at the age of 79, was a native of Hasbrouck Heights."</ref> While a student at Franklin High School (as it was then known) he closed down the school for several days by stuffing Limburger cheese down the heating grates and into the furnace system. * [[Rose Heck]] (born 1932), mayor of Hasbrouck Heights who had earlier served in the [[New Jersey General Assembly]]<ref>[http://web.archive.org/web/20040208152742/http://www.njleg.state.nj.us/members/heck.asp Assemblywoman Heck's Government Website], [[New Jersey Legislature]], backed up by the [[Internet Archive]] as of February 8, 2004. Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref> * [[Willie Moretti|William "Willie" Moretti]] (1894â1951), Mafia gangster who testified before the Anti-Crime Investigation Committee ([[Kefauver Committee]]) and was shot dead in a [[Cliffside Park, New Jersey]] restaurant<ref>Staff. [http://books.google.com/books?id=rFQEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36 "A Gangster is Buried in the Old-Time Style"], ''[[Life (magazine)]]'', October 22, 1951, pp. 36-37. Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref> * [[Bill Parcells]] (born 1941), Executive Vice President of Football Operations for the [[Miami Dolphins]] and former head coach of the [[New York Giants]], [[New England Patriots]], [[New York Jets]] and [[Dallas Cowboys]]<ref>''[[Daily News (New York)]]''. [http://books.google.com/books?id=3dBnpnnM9VQC&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7 ''Parcells''], p. 6, Sports Publishing LLC, 2000. ISBN 1582611467. Accessed March 7, 2011.</ref><ref>Needell, Paul. [http://www.nj.com/sports/ledger/needell/index.ssf/2008/12/for_parcells_there_is_no_great.html "For Parcells, there is no greater game"], ''[[The Star-Ledger]]'', December 27, 2008. Accessed March 7, 2011. "Fifty years ago today, when the course of NFL history changed forever with the so-called ''Greatest Game Ever Played,'' New Jersey's favorite football son did not sit transfixed in front of his family's grainy black-and-white television set in Hasbrouck Heights."</ref><ref>Frias, Carlos. [http://www.palmbeachpost.com/dolphins/content/sports/epaper/2008/08/28/0828parcells.html?cxntlid=inform_artr "Bill Parcells a football man, first and foremost"], ''[[The Palm Beach Post]]'', August 28, 2008. Accessed March 7, 2011. "Bill and Don shared a bed in the family's small house in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J."</ref><ref>[[Frank Litsky|Litsky, Frank]]. [http://www.nytimes.com/1987/01/19/sports/super-bowl-xxi-the-giants-vs-the-broncos-the-two-sides-of-bill-parcells.html "SUPER BOWL XXI: THE GIANTS VS. THE BRONCOS; THE TWO SIDES OF BILL PARCELLS"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', January 19, 1987. Accessed march 7, 2011. "Bill is his nickname. His real name is Duane Charles Parcells, but once he became a teen-ager only his mother called him Duane. He was raised in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J., and everyone knew him as Duane except his fourth-grade teacher. She used to say, ''Duane Parcells, is she here?''"</ref> * Oscar Schwidetzky (1875â1963), philanthropist, inventor of the Ace bandage and the disposable syringe<ref>Blum, June. [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10C14F8395E127A93C5A81782D85F468785F9 "About Hasbrouck Heights"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 17, 1972. Accessed March 7, 2011. "Every athlete is indebted to another native son, the late Oscar Schwidetsky, the unsung hero who developed the Ace Bandage."</ref> * [[Frank Sinatra]] (1915â98), singer and actor<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,823900-7,00.html "The Kid from Hoboken"], ''[[Time (Magazine)]]'', August 29, 1955. Accessed June 4, 2007. "Even at home, Sinatra was not safe. His house in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J. was ringed all day and half the night by gazing girldom. Originally white, its sides were soon smeared with lipstick. Sometimes the girls made human ladders and peered into his bedroom, and when he got a haircut the clippings were claimed."</ref> * [[Scott Slutzker]] (born 1972), former NFL tight end for the [[Indianapolis Colts]], [[New Orleans Saints]], and [[New York Jets]], attended Hasbrouck Heights High School<ref>Eskanazi, Gerald. [http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0915FA345A0C728EDDA10894D9404482 "PRO FOOTBALL; From the Marine Corps To the Tight Ends Corps"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', August 21, 2001. Accessed March 7, 2011. "Becht's backup will most likely be Scott Slutzker, who began his pro career with the Colts in 1996 and is in his first season with the Jets. He grew up a Giants fan in Hasbrouck Heights, N.J."</ref><ref>[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/players/S/SlutSc00.htm Scott Slutzker], Pro-Football-Reference. Accessed September 24, 2008.</ref> * [[Craig L. Williams]] (born 1961), [[LGBT]] activist
